history.content:
I definitely understand the stressful scenario you have. I'll offer my thoughts on the subject, here, and other students/advisers can add on below.

As other students have noted, an NP on your transcript is not very attractive to both graduate admissions, nor the major admissions. Additionally, it may be worth mentioning that there is a very tiny chance you might still pass the course, depending on the professor(s), so technically that would be a gamble, as well. If you are planning on graduate studies in any field, or some related academic goal, then keep in mind that an NP is like an F. It does not factor into your GPA, but some transcript reviewers might factor it in that way.

Thus, I recommend you study hard harder for your final. Redo practice problems and homework problems, do past exams, and don't forget about other resources out there, as well. If you are in a CSM section, ask your mentor any questions. If not, CSM worksheets and review materials are still available to all students, even if they are not enrolled.

Finally, I offer the reminder that you don't have to major in CS if it really comes down to it. There many other options, including the CS minor, CogSci, and other majors, as well, with the CS flavor. On the off chance that declaring CS doesn't end up happening, there are other paths. You don't need to be a CS major to do amazing CS.

That being said, good luck!

children.subject: Thank you very much. If anyone has any other insight, please share.

I think it depends on which grad program you're looking at. For law, for instance, NP counts as an F in GPA calculations which will very likely limit your choice of schools. For PhD, it depends on the particular committee how much they negatively weigh that NP.
Good point. But assuming you are not going to law school, in general, you are fine. Although it's always good to clarify these things directly with an advisor.
great answer above but disagree a bit - a NP doesn't look bad if you end up retaking it and doing really well (getting anywhere in the A range).

history.content:
Hello. I am currently a freshman trying to declare CS (3.3 GPA Cap). I made the decision to take CS61B and CS70 together this semester. Right now, I am doing about average in both classes. I need a B and B+ in both classes, and right now I am afraid that I may end with a B- in cs70.

Of course, it is not decided, but it all depends on my score with the final. It seems the logical approach would be to just study very hard, and make sure I do above average on the final. However, part of me also realizes that this can still be a gamble, as I worked very hard for the midterm 2, and still got the average.

Therefore, I am wondering if anyone might have any advice as to what path I should continue. The only other option I can think of is to P/NP cs70, then fail it on purpose, and retake it next semester. Thank you for reading and I appreciate any advice.
history.subject: Declaring CS: Quick Advice Appreciated
